data.title: Markdown syntax highlighting stops working after `default` keyword is used in TS code block
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider - OS Version: OS X El Capitan Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new Markdown file 2. Paste in this content (taken from the TypeScript Handbook): 
##### JQuery.d.ts

```ts
declare let $: JQuery;
export default $;
```

##### App.ts

```ts
import $ from "JQuery";

$("button.continue").html( "Next Step..." );
```

Classes and function declarations can be authored directly as default exports.
Default export class and function declaration names are optional.
1. You will notice that after the first code block the heading isn't the right color, as if it was treating it as a template string in the TypeScript code. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12286274/16679876/4b5b72da-44a8-11e6-8b3a-270cb415057e.png) 2. Remove the word `default` from the first code block 3. Everything is highlighted properly ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12286274/16679882/59c5f1ec-44a8-11e6-8365-45e535aa9f96.png)

data.title: Menu issues in Ubuntu Unity 16.04

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.0 (e724f269ded347b49fcf1657fc576399354e6703, 2016-07-07T16:50:12.291Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-28-generic

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode
2. Click on a menu
   - see how the window icons (close, minimize, maximize/restore) flicker and are exchanged to app name (usually they stay if you open the menu), just as if the focus goes to an other window.
   - sometimes the "View" menu closes right after opening, but works normal if changing from another menu point to it.

I also had it, that I opened a "New Window" where then the "File" Menu was completely missing.

In the previous version there was the "View" Menu missing after running VSCode for a while. Restart fixed that.

There seems to be a problem with the Unity Menu (global menu) in general.

data.title: [Request] Keep 'Save All' and 'Close All Editors' buttons available when 'OPEN EDITORS' view is collapsed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I've just updated to v1.3 (thanks! it's fantastic). Now with tabs, I've been collapsing the 'OPEN EDITORS' view on the left sidebar to make more room for the folder tree, since the tabs list the open files anyway.

But when the 'OPEN EDITORS' panel is collapsed, the 'Save All' or 'Close All Editors' buttons become unavailable, which is inconvenient as I use those a lot.

Is it possible to keep these two buttons available on the 'OPEN EDITORS' view's header, even when it is collapsed? The space is still there, and the commands are still useful even without the view expanded.

data.title: 'Split Editor' should move the active tab rather than duplicate it

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Xenial

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open 2 code windows, there should be 2 tabs
2. Click the 'split editor' button.
3. Notice the new editor pane has a second instance of the active tab.

I find this annoying. I would prefer behaviour that _moved_ the active tab into the new split, revealing the next-most-recently-used tab in its place.

Preferred workflow goes:
- Editing a file
- Open another file to edit, desire to edit the 2 'top' files side-by-side
- Click 'split'; now the top 2 files are both visible, can edit side-by-side with just one click.

I can't think of a time when I have ever wanted the existing behaviour of duplicating the top tab. It just forces me to follow up the split action with another action to closing the tab in the original split.

data.title: Add openedTextEditors, onDidOpenTextEditor, onDidCloseTextEditor to the extensions API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: OSX

Our extension is rendering decorations in opened editors.

Extensions API has the `window.visibleTextEditors`, `workspace.onDidOpenTextDocument`, and `workspace.onDidCloseTextDocument` that allow to track opened documents and render the decorations in visible editors (and dispose things when the editor is not visible anymore).

Now with the new opened tabs feature, I thought it'd be good not to dispose the decorations if an editor wasn't closed but only became non-visible, but I couldn't find a way to do this with the current API version. I can track opened text documents, but there's no way to get an editor of the document and there's no `window.openedTextEditors`.

It would be great if the API was extended to include:
- `window.openedTextEditors`,
- `window.onDidOpenTextEditor`,
- `window.onDidCloseTextEditor`.

data.title: ASP.NET Debugging No Longer Working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: OSX El Cap 10.11.5
- .NET Core Version: 1.0.0-preview2-003121

Steps to Reproduce:
1. As normal, use debugger for ASP.NET debugging
2. Upgrade VS Code from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0
3. Debugging no longer works. Error message given in VS Code debug console window:

> ERROR: CLRDBG exited unexpectedly with exit code 133 (0x85). Debugging will now abort.
> The program '/Users/Me/MyPath/MyProgram.dll' has exited with code -1 (0xffffffff).

I re-installed .NET Core just to be on the safe side--no difference. I was already running the latest version. I also noticed after I installed the new version of VS Code that a background process re-installed the debug module (? details hazy--I just saw it on the status bar on the bottom of the screen).

data.title: Perl mode fails while tokenizing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: Linux 4.4 (Ubuntu 16.04)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Upgrade to VSCode 1.3
2. Open any Perl file

Along the top, VSCode says

```
Error: The mode has failed while tokenizing the input.
```

Perl mode worked in VSCode 1.0 (sorry, I didn't try 1.1 or 1.2).

**Update**: Wait, not just Perl mode...every mode! I've tried Go, Rust, Ruby, Python. Everything fails to tokenize. Some of them have recommended extensions also.

![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/54600/16675644/fc199862-4490-11e6-883e-df40c68fd932.png)

data.title: Local language support for Version 1.3
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: OS El Capitan 10.11.5

The new version features great, but ignoring the local language translation, if I wanted to go to adjust how to do that?

![](http://i.niupic.com/images/2016/07/08/ZRMehl.jpg)
![](http://i.niupic.com/images/2016/07/08/Rw4bv7.jpg)

data.title: Prevent menu bar from showing up on Windows after Alt+mouse.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Toggle menu bar to hidden.
2. Hold the <kbd>Alt</kbd> key and click the editor to perform a multi-select.
3. Release the <kbd>Alt</kbd> key.
4. The menu bar show up.

The key problem is that when multi-selecting, users DO NOT WANT TO BRING OUT the menu bar. If they want, they will press <kbd>Alt</kbd> solely, without mouse interaction.

Related: #5851
